notes: It seems that the income support specifically covers formal sector employees. See: On June 10, the authorities announced a FCFA 74 billion (US$ 124 million) stimulus package to support formal enterprises, craftsmen and small service trades in the informal sector, in addition to the most vulnerable segments of the population. Measures included in the package are expected to cover 70% of the gross salary of all formal sector employees over the period of three months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200706192006/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The main 'down-town' area of Kinshasa (Gombe) will open up as of 29 June 2020. This means that the following are now open again: stores, banks, public establishments and services, public administrations, public enterprises and commercial companies, industries, restaurants and cafes. The main outdoor market and neighbouring shops, universities, higher institutes and schools and bars remain closed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200629103456/https://www.primature.cd/public/2020/06/24/gombe-a-kinshasa-deconfinement-progressif-des-ce-lundi-29-juin-2020/

The parliament met July 06, 2020 to examine the bill on the 6th extension of the state of health emergency in the DRC - this would extend the state of health emergency for an additional 15 days. The outcome is as yet unclear.     http://web.archive.org/web/20200706174343/https://www.politico.cd/la-rdc-a-la-une/2020/07/06/prorogation-de-letat-durgence-sanitaire-tunda-ya-kasende-empeche-son-adjoint-bernard-takahishe-defend-le-projet-de-loi.html/64243/

"The schools reopening has been announced for 1 July for examination classes."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200706140219/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Mauritania%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20No.%207%20-%201-15%20June%202020.pdf

The VPM stressed that following the recommendations of the Ministry of Health and Wellness, based upon the current situation with no positive Covid-19 case among the population, the Ministry has reworked the school calendar as well as resumption of classes.  Instead of the phased resumption of schools as from 01 August 2020 as announced earlier,  all classes will now resume on 01 July 2020, she indicated. Mrs Leela Devi Dookun-Luchoomun emphasised that a series of measures geared towards ensuring a safe environment will have to be adhered to by students , teaching and non-teaching staff.    link - https://web.archive.org/web/20200615155638/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/New-school-calendar-for-academic-year-2020-revealed-.aspx
Schools remain closed   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.unicef.org/malawi/stories/home-schooling-how-bettie-coping-school-closures

Although there are no official government announcements to close workplaces. However, the government workforce has implemented remote working to reduce the number of people working  in offices at one point in time.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.wateraid.org/mw/our-coronavirus-response

It is government policy that all public events are canceled. There is no ban on  public transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

Some government and private institutions are requiring their workers to work from home. Workinf from home is generally advised where possible.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

there has been no restriction on internal movement  https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

There is a travel ban on international citizens. Airports remain closed but land borders remain open.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

There is a cash transfer program for vulnerable households.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

To support small and medium enterprises (SMEs), commercial banks and micro-finance institutions will be, on a case-by-case basis, restructuring SME loans and providing a three-month moratorium on their debt service.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200629155223/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There is a coordinated public information campaign  https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

Testing is limited to people who are symptomatic and eligible or are contacts of confirmed cases.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

There are improved resources and more personnel to improve covid-19 testing for contact tracing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200629153926/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2019.06.20.pdf

Rwanda has today begun random COVID-19 street testing in Kigali City. Dubbed âDrive through COVID-19 testing,â the movement will test over 5000 people with the aim of getting factual information on the status of COVID-19 in Kigali City and amongst people entering Kigali from different provinces to lead to tactical response to the pandemic.    âThis exercise will be repeated every after two weeks. The outcomes will help in taking proper reactive measures against the COVID-19 pandemic,â says RBC Director General, Dr. Sabin Nsanzimana  https://web.archive.org/web/20200707020508/https://www.rbc.gov.rw/index.php?id=100&tx_news_pi1%255Bnews%255D=570&tx_news_pi1%255Bday%255D=3&tx_news_pi1%255Bmonth%255D=7&tx_news_pi1%255Byear%255D=2020&cHash=b7763e0c13d9a169d6fa82c26b1d36f8

All schools in Tanzania will reopen as of June 29 after three months of closure due to the novel coronavirus, local media reported quoting the countryâs president.    The Mondayâs announcement by President John Magufuli makes Tanzania the first country in East Africa to reopen schools, according to The Citizen local website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200630012557/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/tanzania-to-reopen-schools-after-3-month-closure/1878753
